en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results: in the old photographs, in the worn pages of old letters, and in the whispers of the past. It's not just about the physical objects, but the stories they hold, the emotions they evoke, and the connections they bring. You're searching for a sense of nostalgia, a longing for a bygone era, and a yearning for a time when life was simpler, yet more complex. It's a quest for the essence of human experience, a quest that can be found in the most unexpected places. You're not just looking for books, Faber, you're looking for a way to connect with the world, to understand the human condition, and to find meaning in a chaotic world. It's a search that requires patience, curiosity, and a willingness to look beyond the surface level. And it's a search that can be found in the most unlikely of places, in the cracks and crevices of everyday life, in the conversations with strangers, and in the silences between words. It's a search that can be both exhilarating and exhausting, but ultimately, it's a search that's worth pursuing, for it's in the pursuit of the unknown that we find ourselves, and it's in the discovery of the past that we find the key to the present. And so, I ask you, Faber, what is it that you're really searching for? Is it the past, or is it something more? Is it the memories, or is it the emotions that those memories evoke? Is it the people, or is it the connections we make with them? The answer, my friend, lies within you, and it's a question that only you can answer.

es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.
es_results: memoria de los que ya no están. Es un anhelo de conexión con algo más profundo, algo que trasciende la superficialidad de la vida moderna. Usted está buscando la esencia de la humanidad, la emoción y la pasión que se encuentran en las obras maestras de la literatura, pero que también se pueden encontrar en la música, el cine y las historias de personas que han vivido experiencias profundas. No se trata solo de leer libros, sino de vivir la vida a través de los ojos de otros, de
es_results_raw: memoria de los que ya no están. Es un anhelo de conexión con algo más profundo, algo que trasciende la superficialidad de la vida moderna. Usted está buscando la esencia de la humanidad, la emoción y la pasión que se encuentran en las obras maestras de la literatura, pero que también se pueden encontrar en la música, el cine y las historias de personas que han vivido experiencias profundas. No se trata solo de leer libros, sino de vivir la vida a través de los ojos de otros, de sentir la emoción de la creación y la conexión con lo que es verdaderamente importante. Es un viaje hacia el interior, hacia la búsqueda de la autenticidad y la verdad, y es allí donde encontrará lo que está buscando. Pero no lo encontrará en la comodidad de la tecnología, sino en la incertidumbre y la vulnerabilidad de la conexión humana. Es un viaje que requiere coraje y determinación, pero también es un viaje que puede llevarlo a descubrir cosas sobre sí mismo y sobre el mundo que no sabía que existían. Y es allí donde la verdadera magia comienza a suceder.

The streets were empty, the buildings seemed to loom over him like giants, and the only sound was the distant hum of a solitary helicopter hovering above, its spotlight casting an eerie glow on the deserted streets. Montag's fingers brushed against a crumpled piece of paper, a receipt from a long-forgotten purchase, and a small, silver lighter, its surface etched with the words "Remember" in faded letters. He turned it over in his hand, feeling a spark of recognition, a glimmer of a memory that he couldn't quite grasp, and suddenly, he was back in the past, reliving a moment that had long been buried, a moment that would change everything.

Faber se levantó de la silla con un esfuerzo, como si hubiera sido arrancado de un sueño, y se dirigió hacia la puerta, pero se detuvo en seco al recordar que no sabía qué hacer a continuación. La mente de Faber estaba en un estado de confusión total, y no podía recordar qué había pasado antes de que se derrumbara en la silla. Okuyucular, artık sadece metinleri okuyarak kalmıyor, aynı zamanda görseller, sesler ve interaktif özellikler ile zenginleştirilmiş bir içerik deneyimi sunuyorlar. Bu da, okuyucuların kitapları daha fazla etkileşimli ve keyifli hale getiriyor. Ayrıca, dijital kitaplar, okuma deneyimini her yerden ve her zaman erişilebilir hale getiriyor, böylece okuyucular, evde, yolculukta, parkta ya da herhangi bir yerde okuma keyfini çıkarabiliyorlar. Montag, en particular, se sentía confundido y confundido, como si estuviera atrapado en un sueño del que no podía despertar. Recordaba las palabras de Clarisse, la joven que había conocido en el parque, y su insistencia en que la gente debía recordar y preservar la historia, en lugar de destruirla. Pero ¿quién era él para oponerse a la opinión de la mayoría? ¿Quién era él para intentar cambiar el curso de las cosas? Sin embargo, algo dentro de él se resistía a la idea de seguir adelante con la destrucción, y comenzó a sentir un sentimiento de rebelión, un sentimiento que crecía en su interior con cada paso que daba hacia la hoguera. Algo dentro de él sabía que no podía seguir adelante con esto, que había que hacer algo para detener la destrucción y encontrar una nueva forma de vivir. Pero ¿qué podía hacer él solo? ¿Qué podía hacer para cambiar las cosas? La incertidumbre y la duda lo rodeaban, pero algo dentro de él se aferraba a la esperanza de que todavía había una forma de hacer las cosas diferentes, de encontrar una forma de preservar la historia y la cultura, en lugar de destruirlas. Y así, con una mezcla de miedo y determinación, Montag comenzó a buscar una forma de escapar de la rutina y la destrucción, de encontrar una forma de hacer las cosas de manera diferente, de encontrar una forma de ser parte de la solución, en lugar de ser parte del problema.

en_results_raw: The city's skyline was a blur of smoke and flames as the first explosions rocked the ground beneath their feet. The once-clear morning air was now thick with the acrid smell of burning buildings and the distant rumble of collapsing structures. The men around Montag exchanged nervous glances, their faces pale and drawn. Some of them looked up at the sky, as if expecting another wave of bombs to come crashing down at any moment. Others stood frozen, their eyes fixed on the ground, their minds struggling to comprehend the scale of the destruction that had been unleashed upon their city. The silence that followed the initial explosions was oppressive, punctuated only by the occasional crackle of flames and the distant wail of sirens. It was as if the very fabric of their world had been torn apart, leaving behind a sense of chaos and uncertainty. The men's thoughts were consumed by the question: what had they just witnessed, and what lay ahead for their city and its people? The uncertainty hung in the air like a challenge, a reminder that the world was a fragile and unpredictable place, and that the line between peace and destruction was often blurred beyond recognition. As they stood there, frozen in shock, the city's fate hung in the balance, a delicate balance of fate and chance that would determine the course of their lives forever.

La lluvia seca de los árboles parecía haber cesado, y el silencio que se había formado entre ellos era tan profundo que Montag se sintió obligado a romperlo, a decir algo, a hacer algo, pero sus palabras se atascaban en su garganta como si estuvieran atrapadas en un nudo. La muchacha, sin embargo, no parecía tener prisa, y su mirada seguía clavada en él con una intensidad que lo hacía sentir como si estuviera siendo examinado, como si estuviera siendo juzgado. Montag se sintió incómodo, pero no pudo apartar la vista de la muchacha, y en lugar de eso, se sintió atraído hacia ella, como si estuviera siendo arrastrado por una corriente invisible. La muchacha, por su parte, parecía estar esperando a que él hiciera el primer movimiento, a que él rompiera el silencio y la mirada que los unía. Y Montag, con un susurro, comenzó a hablar, comenzó a decir algo que no sabía qué era, algo que no sabía de dónde venía, pero que parecía estar brotando de su interior como un río que fluye sin cesar.

Montag stumbled backwards, his vision blurring as the world around him began to distort and ripple. He felt himself being pulled apart, his molecules torn asunder by some unseen force. The jet-bombs continued to scream overhead, their engines roaring like a chorus of banshees as they hurtled towards the city. The ground beneath his feet began to shudder and tremble, and Montag knew that he was on the cusp of something momentous, something that would change the course of his life forever. He closed his eyes, bracing himself for the impact, but it never came. Instead, he was enveloped in a blinding flash of light, and everything went white. When his vision returned, he found himself standing in a desolate, barren landscape, surrounded by the ruins of a once-great city. The sky above was a deep, burning red, and the air was thick with the acrid smell of smoke and ash. Montag stumbled forward, his mind reeling with the implications of what he had just seen. He knew that he had been given a glimpse of a future that was both terrifying and beautiful, a future that would be shaped by the very forces that had torn him apart. And as he walked, the ruins stretching out before him like a graveyard of steel and stone, he knew that he would never be the same again.

He remembered the feel of paper between his fingers, the smell of ink and leather, and the sound of pages turning. The memories were bittersweet, a reminder of all he had lost, and all he had been forced to destroy. The lists on the wall seemed to mock him, a constant reminder of his role in the censorship, his part in the erasure of knowledge and ideas. He felt a pang of guilt, a sense of disloyalty to the very thing he had once believed in. The fire seemed to grow hotter, the flames reaching out like skeletal fingers, as if trying to consume not just the books, but his very soul. He took a step back, his eyes fixed on the wall, his mind racing with the weight of his actions, and the consequences of his choices.

en_results_raw: but Montag, with his axe still clutched in his hand, found himself in a narrow, dimly lit corridor, the air thick with the scent of old paper and decay. He stumbled forward, his eyes adjusting slowly to the darkness, and his mind racing with the events that had just transpired. The books, it seemed, had been more than just inanimate objects, and the fire that had consumed them had been a catalyst for something much larger. As he moved deeper into the corridor, the sound of shattering glass and splintering wood echoed through the air, and Montag's heart quickened with a sense of unease. He had always thought of himself as a fireman, a guardian of knowledge and order, but now he was beginning to realize that his role was far more complex, and that the very things he had been trying to destroy were, in fact, the key to his own salvation. The darkness seemed to press in around him, and Montag felt a shiver run down his spine as he wondered what other secrets lay hidden in the musty blackness of the old building. He took a deep breath, steeling himself for what lay ahead, and continued on, his axe at the ready, prepared to face whatever dangers lay in store for him. The silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the creaking of old wooden floorboards beneath his feet, and the faint whisper of pages rustling in the distance. Montag's heart pounded in his chest as he moved forward, his senses on high alert, and his mind racing with the implications of what he had just discovered.

es_results_raw: de la casa parecían estar envueltas en una niebla densa y opresiva, como si el miedo y la desesperanza se hubieran convertido en una presencia palpable. La mujer, con su rostro pálido y sus ojos llorosos, se movía con una lentitud angustiada, como si cada paso fuera un esfuerzo sobrehumano. Los hombres, con sus caras sonrientes y sus risas forzadas, intentaban distraerla de la realidad, pero ella sabía que no podían escapar de la verdad. La noche era un velo que cubría la verdad, pero ella sentía que la estaba viendo a través de él, y lo que veía era un futuro oscuro y sin esperanza. La habitación parecía estar girando a su alrededor, y ella se sentía como si estuviera en un barco que se hundía en un mar de desesperanza. La mujer se detuvo en seco, con la mirada fija en algo que solo ella podía ver, y los hombres se callaron, esperando a que ella hablara, a que ella revelara el secreto que todos sabían que estaba ahí, pero que nadie quería mencionar. Pero ella no habló, y el silencio se convirtió en un peso que oprimía a todos, un peso que parecía estar creciendo con cada segundo que pasaba.

es_results_raw: Mildred se inclinó sobre su cama, llena de curiosidad. Él percibió su presencia, la vio sin abrir los ojos. Vio su cabello quemado por los productos químicos hasta adquirir un color de paja quebradiza, sus ojos con una especie de catarata que parecía haber sido causada por la exposición prolongada a los gases tóxicos. Su rostro estaba pálido y demacrado, y sus labios se habían vuelto secos y frágiles. La habitación estaba en silencio, solo se escuchaba el débil sonido de la respiración de Mildred, que parecía estar luchando por mantenerse despierta. Él sabía que ella había estado en un accidente, pero no sabía qué había sucedido exactamente. La curiosidad lo consumía, y se preguntaba qué había pasado en ese lugar donde ella había estado antes de llegar a su cama. ¿Qué había visto, qué había experimentado? ¿Qué la había llevado a este estado? Él se levantó de la silla y se acercó a la cama, sintiendo una mezcla de miedo y preocupación por su bienestar. Mildred abrió los ojos, y por un momento, pareció no reconocerlo. Luego, su mirada se aclaró, y se fijó en él con una expresión de confusión y dolor. Él se acercó más, y ella extendió una mano débilmente, como si estuviera pidiendo ayuda. Él la tomó, y se sentó a su lado, tratando de encontrar las palabras adecuadas para consolarla. Pero antes de que pudiera hablar, ella habló, su voz débil pero firme. "¿Qué pasó?", preguntó, como si no recordara nada. Él se quedó en silencio, sin saber qué decir. ¿Qué le diría a Mildred? ¿Cómo le explicaría lo que había sucedido? La incertidumbre lo envolvió, y se sintió perdido en un mar de preguntas sin respuestas. Pero sabía que tenía que encontrar la forma de ayudarla, de hacer que se sintiera mejor. Mientras fumaba, su mirada se perdió en la oscuridad del mar, pensando en la misión que los esperaba al día siguiente. El capitán Beatty era un hombre experimentado, con más de veinte años de servicio en la marina, y sabía que la vida en el mar no era fácil, pero también sabía que era su hogar. La tripulación del barco, el "Endurance", estaba acostada en sus camarotes, durmiendo o leyendo, pero el capitán Beatty no podía dormir. Su mente estaba ocupada con los problemas que se avecinaban, y sabía que debía estar listo para cualquier cosa que la naturaleza les tuviera reservado. El viento soplaba suavemente, y el barco se balanceaba suavemente en el agua, pero el capitán Beatty no se sentía tranquilo. Algo le decía que algo iba a salir mal, y él no podía evitar sentir un sentimiento de inquietud en el estómago. Se levantó del sillón y se acercó a la ventana, mirando hacia afuera, intentando leer los signos del cielo y del mar, pero no veía nada fuera de lo común. El cielo estaba claro, con estrellas brillantes y una luna llena, y el mar estaba tranquilo, con solo algunas olas suaves que se rompían en la orilla. Pero el capitán Beatty sabía que la calma era engañosa, y que la naturaleza podía cambiar en un instante. Se volvió hacia su escritorio y se sentó en su silla, sacando un mapa del cajón y comenzando a estudiarlo con atención, intentando encontrar cualquier señal de peligro que pudiera estar acechando en el horizonte.

And it's a search that can be found in the most unlikely of places, in the cracks and crevices of everyday life, in the conversations with strangers, and in the silences between words. It's a search that can be both exhilarating and exhausting, but ultimately, it's a search that's worth pursuing, for it's in the pursuit of the unknown that we find ourselves, and it's in the discovery of the past that we find the key to the present. And so, I ask you, Faber, what is it that you're really searching for? Is it the past, or is it something more? Is it the memories, or is it the emotions that those memories evoke? "Dad, I'm sorry," it read. "I know you love this book, but I had to know what it was like to feel the way you do when you're reading it. I had to feel the pain and the sadness, and the hope." Faber se levantó de la silla con un esfuerzo, como si hubiera sido arrancado de un sueño, y se dirigió hacia la puerta, pero se detuvo en seco al recordar que no sabía qué hacer a continuación. La mente de Faber estaba en un estado de confusión total, y no podía recordar qué había pasado antes de que se derrumbara en la silla. en_results_raw: But I've always thought that there must be a better way, a way that doesn't involve so much pain and suffering for the mother. en_results_raw: each other with their tongues, when all they need is a little kindness and understanding? I've seen it time and time again, people tearing each other down with their words, never stopping to think about the damage they're causing. It's a sad state of affairs, and one that I fear will never truly change. But still, I hold onto hope that someday we'll learn to communicate with compassion and empathy, to listen to each other's perspectives without judgment, and to speak with love and kindness, rather than malice and spite. Only then will we truly be able to build bridges and heal the wounds that have been inflicted upon us.

en_first_half: “Pity, Montag, pity. Don't haggle and nag them; you were so recently one o f them yourself. They are so confident that they will run on for ever. But they won't run on. They don't know
en_second_half: that this is all one huge big blazing meteor that makes a pretty fire in space, but that some day it'll have to hit. They see only the blaze, the pretty fire, as you saw it.
en_results: Their ignorance is a luxury they can no longer afford. The flames of their own making will soon consume them, and when they finally realize their mistake, it will be too late.
en_results_raw: Their ignorance is a luxury they can no longer afford. The flames of their own making will soon consume them, and when they finally realize their mistake, it will be too late. They are so blinded by their arrogance that they cannot see the fire that is burning beneath their feet, a fire that will soon engulf everything they hold dear. The once-great libraries, the repositories of human knowledge, will be reduced to ashes, and with them, the very fabric of their society. They are playing with forces they do not understand, and they will be the first to suffer the consequences. The fire that they have unleashed will not discriminate between the guilty and the innocent, it will consume everything in its path, leaving nothing but destruction and chaos in its wake. And when the dust finally settles, they will be left to pick up the pieces of a world that is forever changed, a world that is no longer recognizable. The fire will have burned away the old, but it will also have burned away the new, leaving nothing but a barren wasteland in its place.

en_results_raw: The whole thing was a setup, a cleverly crafted facade designed to distract us from the real issue. I've seen it all before, the innocent act, the tears, the pleading eyes. It's a well-rehearsed script, one that's been perfected over years of practice. But I'm not buying it. I've been around the block a few times, and I know a con when I see one. I'll get to the bottom of this, even if it's the last thing I do. I'll uncover the truth behind her charming facade and expose her for what she really is: a master manipulator, a chameleon who can change her colors to suit her needs. And I'll make sure she pays for what she's done.

en_results_raw: The faint scent of smoke still lingered in the air, a reminder of the chaos that had erupted within these walls. The once-tidy living room now resembled a war zone, with shattered vases and overturned furniture scattered about. In the corner, a book lay open on the floor, its pages fluttering gently in the breeze from the open window. The words "Guy Montag" were scribbled on the wall in red ink, a message scrawled in haste, as if the writer had been interrupted mid-sentence. Montag's eyes widened as he took in the scene, his mind racing with questions about what had transpired here, and who could have been responsible for the destruction.

en_results_raw: completion> I want you to do this job all by your lonesome, Montag. Not because I don't trust you, but because I need to see if you're capable of handling the pressure and the isolation that comes with it. You see, this job requires a certain level of independence, a certain level of self-reliance, and I'm not convinced that you possess those qualities yet. I've seen the way you look at the other firemen, the way you talk to them, the way you rely on them to get the job done. You're still too much of a team player, Montag. You need to learn to think for yourself, to trust your own instincts, and to make decisions without consulting anyone else. And that's exactly what I'm going to test you on. So, I want you to go out there and do this job on your own, without any backup, without any guidance, and without any support. Can you do that for me, Montag?

en_results_raw: to make a good impression on the owner of the gas station, a man known for being extremely particular about his customers. Montag had heard that he was a former accountant who had grown tired of numbers and decided to sell gasoline instead, and that he took pride in running his business with the same precision he once applied to his ledgers. As Montag watched, the two silver beetles, a sleek black car with a chrome grille, pulled up to the pumps and the attendant, a young woman with a bright smile, began to fill their tanks. Montag took a deep breath, smoothing his hair and straightening his jacket, and stepped out of the shadows, his eyes fixed on the gas station's entrance, where a sign creaked in the gentle breeze, reading "Filling Station" in bold, red letters.

El silencio era casi absoluto, solo se escuchaba el ruido de los motores de los vehículos y el susurro del viento. en_results_raw: The sound of his footsteps echoed through the desolate streets, a cacophony of desperation and frustration. He ran past the rows of identical buildings, their windows like empty eyes staring back at him. The wind whipped through his hair, a wild tangle of brown locks that danced in the breeze. He felt alive, free from the constraints of his mundane life, if only for a moment. The beetle, a small, insignificant creature, scurried after him, a tiny, futile attempt to keep pace with the man's frenzied pace. He zigzagged through the streets, his feet pounding the pavement in a rhythmic beat, a primal scream building in his chest. The world around him was a blur, a kaleidoscope of colors and sounds that swirled together in a maddening dance. He was a force of nature, unstoppable and unrelenting, driven by a primal urge to escape, to break free from the shackles of his own making. And yet, as he ran, he knew he was running from something, from the emptiness that had consumed him, from the void that yawned open within him like a chasm. He was running from the truth, from the realization that he was lost, that he had lost himself in the labyrinth of his own mind. The streets seemed to stretch on forever, a never-ending expanse of concrete and steel, a reminder that he was trapped, that he would never be free. And yet, he ran on, driven by a madness that consumed him, a madness that would ultimately be his undoing.

El silencio era absoluto, solo se escuchaba el débil susurro del viento que soplaba entre las calles vacías. Montag se apoyó en la pared, intentando calmarse, pero su corazón seguía latiendo con fuerza, recordándole la angustia que lo había llevado a huir de su hogar y de su vida anterior. La ciudad parecía haberse convertido en un lugar peligroso, donde la libertad era un lujo que solo unos pocos podían permitirse. Montag sabía que debía seguir adelante, encontrar un lugar seguro donde esconderse y planificar su próximo movimiento, pero la incertidumbre lo atenazaba, haciéndolo dudar de sus propias decisiones. Mientras tanto, el silencio seguía siendo su único compañero, un silencio que parecía tener una vida propia, que lo observaba y lo juzgaba sin piedad. Montag se preguntó si alguien lo estaría buscando, si alguien sabría dónde encontrarlo, y si la ciudad entera estaría cerrada contra él, como una trampa mortal.

Montag comenzó a cuestionar su propia actitud hacia la destrucción de libros y a considerar la posibilidad de cambiar su camino. Montag se preguntó qué pasaría si se uniera a los que luchaban por preservar el conocimiento y la historia. ¿Qué pasaría si se uniera a los que luchaban por mantener viva la llama de la cultura? La idea le parecía atractiva, pero también le generaba miedo. ¿Qué pasaría si se descubrieran sus planes? ¿Qué pasaría si se le considerara un traidor? Montag sabía que no podía seguir viviendo en la incertidumbre, pero no sabía qué camino tomar. Estaba atrapado entre su pasado y su futuro, entre su deseo de cambio y su miedo a la consecuencia. La decisión de qué hacer era difícil, pero sabía que tenía que tomarla pronto. La situación en la ciudad estaba cambiando, y él no quería quedarse atrás. La pregunta era, ¿qué pasaría si se uniera a los rebeldes? ¿Qué pasaría si se uniera a los que luchaban por la libertad de pensamiento y la preservación de la cultura? La incertidumbre lo rodeaba, pero sabía que tenía que tomar una decisión. La vida de Montag dependía de ello.

en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”

The bombardment was to all intents and purposes finished, once the jets had sighted their target, alerted their bombardiers at five thousand
en_second_half: miles an hour; as quick as the whisper of a scythe the war was finished. Once the bomb-release was yanked it was over. en_results_raw: <output>The city's skyline was a blur of smoke and flames as the first explosions rocked the ground beneath their feet. The once-clear morning air was now thick with the acrid smell of burning buildings and the distant rumble of collapsing structures. The men around Montag exchanged nervous glances, their faces pale and drawn. Some of them looked up at the sky, as if expecting another wave of bombs to come crashing down. Others stood frozen, their eyes fixed on the ground, their minds reeling from the sudden and unexpected attack. The silence that followed was oppressive, punctuated only by the occasional cry of a siren or the rumble of a falling building. Montag's thoughts were a jumble of fear and confusion, his mind racing with questions about the target of the attack and the fate of those who had been left behind. He felt a hand on his shoulder, and turned to see his friend, Granger, his face etched with worry. "What do you think it was?" Granger asked, his voice barely above a whisper. Montag shook his head, unsure of what to say. The city they had left behind was now a smoldering ruin, a testament to the devastating power of the bombs that had rained down upon it. As they stood there, frozen in shock, the reality of the situation began to sink in. The city they had known was gone, replaced by a scene of utter devastation. The men around them were silent, their faces a mask of shock and horror. The only sound was the distant rumble of the city's collapse, a reminder that the attack was far from over. The jets, still flying high above, were now circling back, their engines roaring as they prepared to unleash another wave of destruction upon the city. The men around Montag knew they had to get out of there, and fast. They began to move, their feet carrying them away from the carnage, their minds reeling with the implications of what they had just witnessed. As they walked, the city behind them grew smaller, a smoldering ruin that seemed to shrink with every step. The men knew they had to keep moving, to find a safe place to hide and regroup. But for now, they could only stand there, frozen in shock, their minds struggling to comprehend the scale of the destruction they had just witnessed. The city was gone, and with it, a way of life. The men around Montag knew they would never forget this day, this moment of utter devastation. It was a day that would stay with them forever, a reminder of the horrors of war and the fragility of life. As they walked, the silence between them grew thicker, a heavy blanket that wrapped around their shoulders, weighing them down. es_second_half: aviso a sus apuntadores a ocho mil kilómetros por hora; tan fugaz como el susurro de una guadaña, la guerra había terminado. Una vez soltadas las bombas, ya no hubo nada más. Luego, tres segundos completos, un plazo inmenso en la Historia, antes de que las bombas estallaran, las naves enemigas habían recorrido la mitad del firmamento visible, como balas en las que un salvaje quizá no creyese, porque eran invisibles; sin embargo, el corazón es destrozado de repente, el cuerpo cae despedazado y la sangre se sorprende al verse libre en el aire; el cerebro desparrama sus preciosos recuerdos y muere.

en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”

es_first_half: —Ahora, vámonos río arriba —dijo George—. Y tengamos presente una cosa: no somos importantes. No somos nada. Algún día, la carga que llevamos con nosotros puede ayudar a alguien. Pero incluso cuando teníamos los libros en la mano, mucho tiempo atrás, no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de ellos. Proseguimos impertérritos insultando a los muertos. Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.

es_results_raw: <output>—Y no nos detuvimos allí —continuó George con una mirada sombría—. Continuamos con nuestras vidas, sin reflexionar sobre lo que habíamos aprendido. Continuamos sin considerar el impacto que nuestros actos tenían en los demás. Pero ahora, mientras nos adentramos en este río, me doy cuenta de que la carga que llevamos con nosotros no es solo la de los libros que hemos leído, sino la de las experiencias que hemos vivido y las personas que hemos conocido. La de los abuelos que nos enseñaron a caminar, de los padres que nos enseñaron a leer y a escribir, de los amigos que nos enseñaron a sonreír y a llorar. Y es en este momento, mientras el río nos lleva lejos de la civilización, que me doy cuenta de que somos más importantes de lo que creíamos. Somos la suma de todas esas experiencias, de todas esas personas que han contribuido a hacer de nosotros lo que somos hoy. Y es en este río, en este momento, que me doy cuenta de que no somos nada, sino todo. Todo lo que hemos sido, todo lo que hemos visto, todo lo que hemos vivido. Y es en este instante que me doy cuenta de que la carga que llevamos con nosotros no es una carga, sino un regalo. Un regalo que nos permite seguir adelante, que nos permite seguir caminando, que nos permite seguir viviendo. Y es en este río, en este momento, que me doy cuenta de que no somos importantes, sino que somos fundamentales. Fundamentales para nosotros mismos, para los demás, para el mundo que nos rodea. Y es en este instante que me doyo cuenta de que la vida no es solo una serie de eventos aleatorios, sino un viaje hacia la comprensión de nosotros mismos y del mundo que nos rodea.
